chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In every sinner who is already using their free will, the benefit of divine grace begins through the conversion of the heart. However, we know that infants are saved not by their own will, but by the righteous faith of the faithful who confess on their behalf.

It is fitting, according to the judgment of truth, that infants are absolved through the ministry of another's confession, as they are bound by the tie of another's sin. So, through the spiritual confession of others, they receive the benefit of justification, just as they bear original sin through the carnal generation of others. As the carnal union of parents harmed those not yet born and doing nothing, the spiritual affection of the faithful confessing on their behalf may benefit them in their second birth.

Therefore, as far as those who can already account for their own actions are concerned, no one will be made blessed unless they renounce their evil deeds and turn to God with total humility of heart. Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered. Psalms 32:1.

Therefore, anyone who bears the iniquity of their own will and actions cannot receive any blessing unless they turn to the very giver of blessings.
chunks.original_latin:
In omni ergo peccatore qui arbitrio jam propriae
voluntatis utitur, per conversionem cordis beneficium
divini muneris inchoatur. Caeterum parvulos
novimus non propria voluntate, sed fidelium pro eis
confitentium recta credulitate salvari. Convenit enim
judicio veritatis parvulos ministerio alienae confessionis
absolvi, quos vinculo constat alienae iniquitatis
obstringi: ut, aliis spiritaliter confitentibus, accipiant
justificationis beneficium, qui, aliis carnaliter
generantibus, portant originale peccatum; et sicut
ad primam nativitatem obfuit nondum natis nec
aliquid agentibus parentum carnalis concubitus, sic
eis nescientibus prosit ad secundam nativitatem fidelium
pro eis confitentium spiritalis affectus. Quantum
 ergo ad illos attinet qui propriorum jam possunt actuum
reddere rationem, nullus efficietur beatus,
nisi qui malis actibus renuntians, ad Deum fuerit
tota cordis humilitate conversus. Beati enim quorum
remissae sunt iniquitates, et quorum tecta sunt peccata
(Psal XXXI 1). Quisquis igitur propriae voluntatis et
operationis iniquitatem portat, non potest aliquam
accipere beatitudinem, nisi fuerit ad ipsum conversus
beatitudinis largitorem.
